15 March 2016

Pepper's Ghost

DIY Augmented Reality Device

My challenge for myself was creating a 0$ augmented reality device, with only materials I already had or I could find in the trash. Here is what you’ll need:

  • a piece of cardboard (12.5X13.75 inch)
  • a small piece of clear acrylic (5.5X4.6 inch)
  • 2 paper binders or a rubber band
  • super glue

The design is based on the Google Cardboard design, which I modified to fir the augmented reality device

original Cardboard design vs. Augmented reality device

click here to get the file for laser cutting. Cut out the bigger piece from cardboard and the smaller piece from clear acrylic. The red lines are half cuts (for folding). Green and black lines are through cuts.

You’re almost done! Now just fold the cardboard, pushing flaps to matching slots.

At this point, if you are using a rubber band and not paper binders, slide the band on the top part, where the phone will sit later. Now use the super glue and glue the thin piece of cardboard to the acrylic, pushing the flap in the acrylic piece into the slot at the front of the folded cardboard, creating a 45 degrees angle between the acrylic and cardboard. This will give us the pepper’s ghost effect!

It should look like that:

Then, just put and image or video with a black background on your phone and lay it on top of you device. Use the rubber band or paper binders to hold it so it doesn’t move



Ta-da! You have made a 0$ worth augmented reality device!! Not bad compared to a 3000$ HoloLens :)




Following improvements we discussed in class will be showing two images (using an app similar to the Google Cardboard app used for YouTube videos), and adding a small piece of cardboard to split between the two eyes, so you can focus both on the augmented image and the background at the same time. If I had found a thiner piece of acrylic in the shop’s trash, I could also avoid the double image, but this is for the 5$ version of the device.
